Text.val: Delete the existing records, so the list will be empty

ExpSyntax.val: 'DV16: How Do I React to the Scenario Where There Are No Records in the View?'

Text.val: The Address Book Header is opened here in Read mode, and only Query is allowed.
Call task to add a record
Then Refresh the data view so the record appears on the list
Call task to add a record
Then Refresh the data view so the record appears on the list
Call task to delete the current record
Then Refresh the data view so the record disappears
The initial mode and record are passed in, allowing this task to do double duty.
Delete the record in the parent task
The initial mode of this task is Delete mode, so any records selected will be deleted.
The Address Book Header is opened here in Read mode, and only Query is allowed.
Change mode so the user can add a record
Magic handles the refreshing etc., so there isn't much else to do
To modify the record, the user has to be in Modify mode.
F5 toggles the task between Modify and Query
Change mode to modify, if needed

Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs20 This list is opened in Query mode, but the other modes (Modify, Create, Delete) are also allowed. \par \par The result is a kind of multi-purpose list. This is convenient for the advanced user, and Magic handles the details for screen updating.\par \par However, it also has a few disadvantages:\par \par - There may be more record locking. \par \par - The Data source is opened in Write mode, and the user can inadvertently modify records if they aren't careful\par \par - It is more difficult to display many fields in a "list" format\par \par - The user has more control and the programmer has less control, which can make design more difficult.\par }
